Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Expectation2: Complete any assignments or tasks given by the mentor.
Situation2: The mentor suggested some optional reading and the informal deadline is weeks away.
Story: It’s Saturday afternoon, and my phone buzzes with a message from Mom: “Hope you’re having a good weekend! Call us when you can.” I glance at the screen, feeling a familiar tug of guilt. I haven’t called home in over a week, and I know my parents worry if I go too long without checking in. I type out a quick reply—“Will call soon!”—but don’t hit send. My laptop is open in front of me, a PDF from my mentor staring back at me. She’d suggested I read a few chapters, not urgent, but she always notices who takes initiative. I want to impress her, to show I’m serious about my growth. But the thought of calling home lingers, the expectation to be a good son pressing on me. I can’t focus on the reading, but I can’t bring myself to call either, knowing it’ll turn into a long conversation. I sit there, torn, the weight of both roles heavy on my shoulders, unsure which expectation to meet first.
